Graphical abstract CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces have been investigated through the density functional theory (DFT) method together with periodic slab models. Effect of different surface structures on adsorption, reaction and catalytic activity has been explored. CO at different adsorption sites participated in the oxidative coupling reaction according to the surface structure. CO at bridge or hollow site was consumed for the coupling reaction on the Pd(100) surface, and the favorable route was COOCH3-COOCH3 coupling path. While CO-COOCH3 coupling route was the optimal on Pd(110) and (211) surfaces, CO at top and bridge site took part in the reaction, respectively. Pd(100) surface exhibited higher catalytic activity and selectivity to DMO than Pd(110) and (211) surfaces. Keywords CO oxidative coupling to DMO Surface structure Pd catalyst Density functional theory 1 Introduction Ethylene glycol is an important chemical raw material and widely used in various fields. Coal to ethylene glycol (CTEG) is the key technology to solve the market risk [1–4]. CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) is the most pivotal reaction in CTEG [5], and its important position in C1 chemistry has been widely approved by scholars [6,7]. The core catalyst for this reaction has been proved to be the palladium based catalyst [8,9]. As we all know, palladium has many different crystal surface structures, and the reaction mechanism of the same reaction on different crystal surfaces is greatly different [10–12].Therefore judging the active surface for CO oxidative coupling to DMO has become a very valuable research topic. Pd(111) was proved to be an active surface for CO oxidative coupling reaction [13]. In our previous work [14], a series of Pd cluster structures with different sizes had been studied, Al13@Pd42 and Al@Pd12 have the similar surface structural properties with Pd(111) which exhibits excellent catalytic performance for DMO formation. In addition, Pd(100) is also a main exposed surface on Pd metal owing to the lower surface energy. And it has been generally recognized that the (100) surface of face-centered cubic metals is usually with high activity in catalytic reaction [15–19]. The oxidation of Hg has been efficiently carried out on the Pd(100) surface by the first-principles calculations [20]. At the same time, some studies have pointed out that Pd(100) surface exhibited a good performance in the adsorption and activation of CO [21–26]. Besides Pd(111) and (100) surfaces, Pd(110) is also a low index crystal surface, and has been recognized an outstanding catalytic performance [27]. Pd(110) surface showed a high catalytic activity on the N2O-CO reaction by kinetic analysis [28]. Meanwhile, this surface also has a certain activation capacity to CO [29]. In addition, Pd(211) is a typical high index crystal surface, and there are a lot high density step atoms in its structure and make the surface have a good catalytic activity [30]. At the same time, the high catalytic performance of Pd(211) surface has been proved in many works [31,32]. Pd(211) surface exhibited a certain positive effect on the adsorption and activation of CO [33,34]. In our previous work [35], a good catalytic activity for the reduction of NO via H2 have been obtained on the Pd(211) surface. Therefore, it is necessary to explore the catalytic performance of Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces aiming at CO oxidative coupling to DMO. In this work, we will clarify the reaction process of CO oxidative coupling to DMO on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation. At the same time, the role of different surface structures in adsorption, reaction and catalytic activity will be analyzed. Additionally, the activity and selectivity of different surfaces will be compared. We hope to further understand the effect of different surfaces on CO oxidative coupling to DMO via this work. 2 Methodology and models Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) software was adopted in this work [36–38]. The ions-electrons interaction was described by the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [39] exchange-correlation functional was used in this work. And the plane wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 400 eV was used. Different slab models with various surface sizes were built. A p(3 × 4) supercell with the surface size of 8.391 × 11.188 Å2 containing three atomic layers was modeled for Pd(100) surface. Pd(110) and (211) surfaces were modeled by p(3 × 4, 11.867 × 11.188 Å2) with five atomic layers and p(2 × 4, 13.702 × 11.188 Å2) with eight atomic layers, respectively. Therefore, different Brillouin zone k-point samplings were selected for these three surfaces. Adsorption energies of CO at the bridge site over the Pd(100) surface with k-points of (2 × 1 × 1), (3 × 2 × 1), (4 × 3 × 1) and (5 × 4 × 1) were calculated, which are -181.7, -186.5, -183.0 and -181.7 kJ·mol−1 (see Table 1 ). It can be seen that the adsorption energy does not change very much when k-point mesh increases, implying (2 × 1 × 1) as k-point for Pd(100) surface is suitable. Moreover, the corresponding adsorption energies of CO at the Pd top site with k-point of (2 × 2 × 1), (3 × 3 × 1), (4 × 4 × 1) and (5 × 5 × 1) are -123.3, -143.6, -142.5 and -142.8 kJ·mol-1 over Pd(110) surface, respectively. It is not difficult to find that the k-point of (3 × 3 × 1) is sufficient on the Pd(110) surface. In addition, there has little influence on the adsorption of CO at the bridge site when k-point mesh increases from (2 × 2 × 1), (3 × 3 × 1), (4 × 4 × 1) up to (5 × 5 × 1) on the Pd(211) surface, implying that the k-point of (2 × 2 × 1) is adequate on the Pd(211) surface. The atomic structures were relaxed until the electronic energy was less than 1 × 10−5 eV and force was less than 0.03 eV·Å-1 for unconstrained atoms. The Climbing-image Nudged Elastic Band method (CI-NEB) [40,41] combining with the dimer method [42,43] was used for locating transition state (TS) for every elementary step, in which the force was converged to 0.05 eV/Å. Vibrational frequency calculation was done and only one virtual frequency was obtained to confirm the TS structure. The optimized lattice parameter of palladium bulk is 3.955 Å, which is in line with the experimental data of 3.891 Å [44]. For Pd(100) surface model, the third layer was frozen in the bulk position, other layers and adsorbed species were allowed to relax. For Pd(110) and Pd(211) surfaces, they were allowed to relax the top two and four layers, respectively, and the rest of layers were fixed. And all species on these three surfaces were allowed to relax. The structures and adsorption sites on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces are shown in Fig. 1 , in which only seven sites on the (211) surface intera E a = E T S − E R cting with different species in DMO formation are exhibited. The activation energy (E a) can be obtained by the following Equation: (1) E a = E T S − E R The adsorption energy (E ads) is defined as following formula: (2) E a d s = E s l a b / a d s o r b a t e − E s l a b − E a d s o r b a t e where Eslab/adsorbate is the total energy of an adsorption system, Eslab represents the energy of different surfaces and Eadsorbate is the energy of the isolated adsorbate in the gas phase. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Pathways for CO oxidative coupling to DMO Due to the bond dissociation energy between NO and OCH3 in CH3ONO is very small [45], and which can be dissociated easily [46]. Therefore, we will directly consider the OCH3 radical initiating the reaction of CO oxidative coupling to DMO. Two pathways for CO oxidative coupling to DMO are obtained [47], as shown in Fig. 2 . They are named by the different ways of coupling carbon atoms, including COOCH3 coupling with COOCH3 (Path 1) and CO coupling with COOCH3 (Path 2). DMC formation will be considered in this coupling reaction, and the selectivity to DMO for different Pd surfaces will be elucidated by comparing the formation of DMC. In this work, the adsorption of reactants on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces will be first studied, and the different adsorption effect of these three surfaces on reactants will be elucidated. 3.2 Adsorption properties of reactants, possible intermediates and products Possible adsorption configurations of reactants (CO and OCH3), intermediates, and products on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces are investigated. Adsorption energies and structures on the Pd(100) surface are shown in Fig. 3 . Reactant CO can be stable at all adsorption sites on the Pd(100) surface, and the adsorption energies of CO at bridge, top and hollow sites are -181.7, -145.1 and -169.8 kJ·mol−1, respectively. But OCH3 can only stable exist at bridge and hollow sites, and the adsorption energy are -201.2 and -192.8 kJ·mol−1, respectively. It is different that the adsorption of OCH3 on the Pd(111) surface, which can stably exist at all surface sites [48]. For intermediates COOCH3 and OCCOOOCH3, there is only one bridge adsorption on the Pd(100) surface, and adsorption energies are -205.2 and -249.4 kJ·mol−1, as shown in Fig. 3. Product DMO is adsorbed weakly on the Pd(100) surface, which is a typical physisorption with an adsorption energy of -24.8 kJ·mol−1, which is similar to that on the Pd(111) surface with an energy of -13.6 kJ·mol−1 [48]. The adsorption configurations of different species on the Pd(110) surface are shown in Fig. 4 . First of all, there are five stable adsorption configurations for CO, include two different bridge sites, top, fcc and hcp sites. The corresponding adsorption energies are -190.5, -145.0, -143.6, -176.6 and -141.8 kJ·mol−1, respectively. Adsorption configurations of OCH3 on two kinds of bridge sites and one top site are obtained, and the adsorption energies of these configurations are -202.9, -175.1 and -176.5 kJ·mol−1, respectively. COOCH3 can be adsorbed at one kind of bridge site and top site, they are via C–O bond and C atom binding with the Pd(110) surface, and the adsorption energy are -221.2 and -196.9 kJ·mol−1, respectively. OCCOOCH3 can only be stably adsorbed at top site and the adsorption energies is -244.1 kJ·mol−1. On the Pd(110) surface, the adsorption of DMO is also a physisorption with an adsorption energy of -35.9 kJ·mol−1. As shown in Fig. 5 . CO has five stable adsorption configurations on the Pd(211) surface including bridge, top, fcc, hcp, and hollow sites, and the corresponding adsorption energies are -195.5, -151.1, -185.7, -194.8 and -156.4 kJ·mol−1, respectively. OCH3 can be adsorbed at bridge and fcp sites, the adsorption energies are -242.4 and -192.2 kJ·mol−1, respectively. COOCH3 can be adsorbed at bridge site via C–O bond binding with Pd(211) surface, and the adsorption energy is -249.1 kJ·mol−1. OCCOOCH3 can also be stable adsorbed at bridge site with an adsorption energy of -264.2 kJ·mol−1. It is similar to the adsorption of HCOO and COOH on the stepped Au(211) surface, and the bridge site at edge is the stable adsorption site [49]. The adsorption of DMO is still a physical adsorption on the Pd(211) surface, and the adsorption energy of DMO is only -30.0 kJ·mol−1. In addition, the adsorption of intermediate OCCO investigated on the Pd(111) surface [48] has also been studied, but which cannot stably exist on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces. Moreover, we consider the influence of dispersion corrections on the bonding strength between surfaces and large molecules, the configurations and adsorption energies of COOCH3 and OCCOOOCH3 on these three surfaces with and without dispersion correction are presented in Table 2 . Adsorption energies of COOCH3 and OCCOOCH3 with dispersion correction are -205.0 and -249.7 kJ·mol−1, respectively. There are little differences comparing with results without dispersion correction (-205.2 and -249.4 kJ·mol−1), implying that dispersion correction has hardly any effect on the Pd(100) system. Similarly, little influence has been found for adsorptions of COOCH3 (-193.4/-196.9 kJ·mol−1) and OCCOOCH3 (-240.5/-244.1 kJ·mol−1) on the Pd(110) surface with and without dispersion correction. On the (211) surface, adsorption energies of COOCH3 and OCCOOCH3 with dispersion correction are -241.2 and -256.5 kJ·mol−1, which are very close to the values of -249.1 and -264.2 kJ·mol-1 without dispersion correction. Meanwhile, the main bond lengths of COOCH3 and OCCOOCH3 change less than 0.01 Å after correction of dispersion. It can be seen that little diﬀ ;erence exists when the dispersion correction is added into system. Therefore, dispersion correction is neglected in this study. 3.3 CO oxidative coupling to DMO on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces 3.3.1 CO oxidative coupling on the Pd(100) surface The reaction begins with the formation of the co-adsorption configuration of CO and OCH3, and there are two stable co-adsorption configurations which can be formed by CO and OCH3. They are CO-B−OCH3-B and CO-H−OCH3-B, respectively (OCH3 adsorbs at bridge site, while CO adsorbs at bridge and hollow sites). At the same time, the COOCH3 at the bridge site has been selected as the product in the first elementary reaction. We have tested the energy barrier of these two co-adsorption configurations to generate COOCH3, the configurations of corresponding species and potential energy diagram are shown in Fig. 6 . We can find that the required activation energies for two types of the first elementary reaction are 54.0 or 53.0 kJ·mol−1, the gap is only 1.0 kJ·mol−1. It is noteworthy that the energy of TS1Pd(100)(a) is almost the same as the TS1Pd(100)(b). And the difference in activation energy mainly comes from the energy gap between two reactants (CO-B−OCH3-B-385.8 kJ·mol−1, CO-H−OCH3-B-384.4 kJ·mol−1). So it can be come to a conclusion that there are two ways to generate COOCH3 on the Pd(100) surface, which are co-existence. It is different that the formation of COOCH3 on the Pd(111) surface, both CO and OCH3 at the top site participate in the reaction with an energy barrier of 38.1 kJ·mol−1 [48]. In this process, the distances between C atom of CO and O atom of OCH3 in CO-B−OCH3-B and CO-H−OCH3-B are shorten to 1.408 Å from 3.764 Å and 3.910 Å. And the distances are 1.699 and 1.689 Å in TS1Pd(100)(a) and TS1Pd(100)(b), respectively. The formation of the second COOCH3 is very similar to the first COOCH3, this process is accompanying by an endothermic energy of 41.4 kJ·mol−1 and needs to overcome an energy barrier of 50.1 kJ·mol−1, and finally leading to the formation of two COOCH3 (2COOCH3 *). During this elementary reaction, only adsorption structure of the second CO at the bridge site is obtained due to the effect of steric hindrance, and the adsorbed species are with the order of OCH3(B), CO(H) and COOCH3(B) from left to right on the Pd(100). Certainly, the co-adsorption configuration with the order of CO(H), OCH3(B) and COOCH3(B) from left to right is also considered, as Fig. S1 at Supporting information. However, CO is eventually adsorbed stably at the bridge site. In addition, the formation of two COOCH3 is also investigated when this co-adsorption configuration is used as the reactant. The result shows that the formed two COOCH3 are far away from each other with a long CC distance of 6.123 Å, and the coupling process leading to the formation of DMO has been studied, but filed. It implies that the coupling reaction will not occur via these two COOCH3 with a long distance. So this co-adsorption configuration is not further investigated. In the end of Path 1, the DMO is formed by the coupling of two COOCH3 via a transition state [TS3Pd(100)]. This step is accompanying by a high energy barrier (129.9 kJ·mol−1) and an endothermic energy of 46.4 kJ·mol−1. In TS3Pd(100), the distance between C atoms of two COOCH3 is shorten to 1.981 from 4.180 Å, and ultimately become 1.532 Å in DMO. The first reaction step in Path 2 is the same as Path 1, as shown in Fig. 7 . In the next reaction step, another CO is adsorbed at bridge site and forms a co-adsorption configuration with COOCH3 (COOCH3 *+CO*). The distance between two C atoms of CO and COOCH3 in this structure is 3.836 Å. Then the COOCH3 attacks CO to form the OCCOOCH3 via a transition state [TS4Pd(100)], and the distance between two C atoms will be shorten to 1.865 Å in TS4Pd(100) and be further shorten to 1.536 Å in OCCOOCH3. This reaction needs to conquer an energy barrier of 157.9 kJ·mol−1 and accompanies an endothermic energy of 109.0 kJ·mol−1. By the way, this step is the rate-limiting step of Path 2 on the Pd(100) surface. In the last reaction step, OCH3 and OCCOOCH3 form a stable intermediate (OCCOOCH3 *+OCH3 *), like previous steps, OCH3 is still adsorbed at bridge position in this structure. Then the OCH3 approaches OCCOOCH3 to form DMO via a transition state [TS5Pd(100)]. An activation energy of 129.4 kJ·mol−1 is needed in this process with an exothermic energy of 13.4 kJ·mol−1. It is not difficult to find that DMO tends to be generated through the coupling of two COOCH3 on the Pd(100) surface, which is very consistent with the phenomena observed by Ji et al. [50]. 3.3.2 DMO formation on the Pd(110) surface In order to optimize the path of the first elementary reaction on the Pd (110) surface, the same test has been carried out. Correlation structures and potential energy diagram are shown in Fig. 8 . COOCH3 adsorbed at the top site on the Pd(110) surface with a low adsorption energy has been selected as product. There are eight kinds of stable co-adsorption configurations between CO and OCH3, but only six transition states for the formation of COOCH3 are obtained. It can be found that the required activation energy is the lowest [92.5 kJ·mol−1 at TS1Pd(110)(a)] when CO and OCH3 adsorbed at top and B2 sites, respectively. Followed by the first step, a co-adsorption configuration of another CO and OCH3 with the first COOCH3 (COOCH3 *+CO*+OCH3 *) leads to the formation of the second COOCH3 via a transition state [TS2Pd(110)], where the distance between O atom and C atom is shorten to 2.063 from 3.713 Å. This process is with a small exothermic energy (1.0 kJ·mol−1) and needs to overcome an energy barrier of 101.7 kJ·mol−1 (Fig. 9 ). In the final stage of Path 1, two COOCH3 couple to DMO via the TS3Pd(110), an energy barrier of 187.3 kJ·mol−1 is needed to cross the transition state with an endothermic energy of 40.5 kJ·mol−1. In TS3Pd(110), the distance between C atoms of two COOCH3 is shorten to 2.202 Å from 5.445 Å in 2COOCH3 *. The related reaction process for Path 2 on the Pd(110) surface is shown in Fig. 10 . The formed COOCH3 via the first step attacks CO to form an OCCOOCH3, and the length of new formed CC bond in OCCOOCH3 is 1.544 Å. This process needs go through a transition state [TS4Pd(110)], and an energy barrier of 177.0 kJ·mol−1 is needed to complete this process (Fig. 10). In TS4Pd(110), the distance between the C atom of COOCH3 and CO will be shorten to 2.187 from 5.767 Å in COOCH3 *+CO*. Then, OCH3 adsorbed at the top site approaches to the formed OCCOOCH3 leading to the formation of DMO. This process must overcomes an energy barrier of 59.3 kJ·mol−1 and accompanied an exothermic energy of 38.5 kJ·mol−1. It can be seen that CO oxidative coupling to DMO mainly occurs at top and bridge sites on the Pd(110) surface, while fcc and hcp sites are not active sites for the reaction. It is in agreement with the water gas shift reaction on the Ni(110) surface, CO binds with surface at the bridge site and H2O adsorbs on the surface via oxygen atom at top site, and the reaction between CO and H2O is at top and bridge sites [51]. 3.3.3 CO oxidative coupling to DMO on the Pd(211) surface The co-adsorption configuration of CO and OCH3 at two adjacent top sites is studied in the first place. However, both of them move to the stable position (bridge site) after optimization. Therefore there are only three kinds of co-adsorption configurations for CO and OCH3 on the Pd(211) surface. As shown in Fig. 11 , when the CO and OCH3 located at bridge site simultaneously, the required activation energy is the lowest to generate COOCH3 (119.0 kJ·mol−1) via a transition state [TS1Pd(211)(a)]. The generation of the second COOCH3 is equivalent to a repetition reaction process of generating the first COOCH3 but at different environment. In COOCH3 *+CO*+OCH3 *, COOCH3 occupies bridge site at step edge, CO and OCH3 adsorb on the bridge site at adjacent step edge. By overcoming an energy barrier of 119.1 kJ·mol−1 and accompanying an endothermic energy of 33.8 kJ·mol−1, finally leading to the formation of 2COOCH3 * on the Pd(211) surface (Fig. 12 ). In TS2Pd(211), the distance between OCH3 and CO is shorten to 2.037 from 3.163 Å, and the distance will be further shortened to 1.256 Å in 2COOCH3 *. The following coupling process of 2COOCH3 * on the Pd(211) surface must overcomes a very high energy barrier (251.8 kJ·mol−1) via a transition state [TS3Pd(211)], and with an endothermic energy of 107.0 kJ·mol−1. The distance between C atoms of the two COOCH3 is shorten to 2.088 Å from 7.051 Å in 2COOCH3 *. And the length of CC bond will be eventually shortened into 1.535 Å in DMO. The relative energy diagram for Path 2 on the Pd(211) surface is shown in Fig. 13 . The second elementary reaction is that the COOCH3 attacks CO to generate OCCOOCH3 located at bridge site at edge, implying that the edge on the stepped surface plays an important role for the reaction, especially for big molecules. The formation of ethanol via CO hydrogenation mainly occurs at edge on the Rh(211) surface [10]. A transition state [TS4Pd(211)] is undergone and an activation energy of 239.6 kJ·mol−1 is needed. And then DMO is formed by OCH3 interacting with OCCOOCH3 via a transition state [TS5Pd(211)], which is an endothermic process (22.2 kJ·mol−1) and needs an activation energy of 115.7 kJ·mol−1. In TS5Pd(211), the distance between C and O of OCCOOCH3 and OCH3 is shorten to 3.596 from 6.768 Å, and ultimately becomes 1.333 Å in DMO. 3.4 Micro-kinetic modeling The micro-kinetic modeling has been extensively used in describing and analyzing the activity of catalysts [52–57]. The difference in the rate of DMO’s formation between pure Pd(111) and Pd-Al(111) surfaces by micro-kinetic modeling has been well investigated in our previous work [48]. In order to further understand the effects of these three surfaces on CO oxidative coupling to DMO, we have also carried out the calculation of corresponding kinetic. All the reactions contained in the whole reaction process are listed in Table 3 . The rate constant (ki ) is calculated as following equations: [58,59] (3) k i = v i exp − E a R T (4) v i = k B T h ∏ i = 1 3 N [ 1 − exp ( − h f i I S k B T ) ] ∏ i = 1 3 N − 1 [ 1 − exp ( − h f i T S k B T ) ] where f i I S and f i T S are vibrational frequencies of initial states and transition states, and kB is Boltzmann constant. The equilibrium relationship between the reaction species involved in the reaction and the free site (θ *) can be described as formula (5), and the results are shown in Table 4 . (5) θ C O + θ O C H 3 + θ C O O C H 3 + θ O C C O O C H 3 + θ * = 1 The coverage of OCH3 and CO on the surfaces can be obtained by the following formulas (6) and (7). Meanwhile the coverage of other reactants on surfaces can be described according to the steady-state approximation [60], and can be got by the following formulas (8) and (9): (6) θ O C H 3 = P O C H 3 K O C H 3 θ * (7) θ C O = P C O K C O θ * (8) θ C O O C H 3 : d θ C O O C H 3 d t = k 1 θ O C H 3 θ C O + k 2 θ O C H 3 θ C O − k 3 θ C O O C H 3 2 − k 4 θ C O O C H 3 θ C O − k 6 θ C O O C H 3 θ O C H 3 = 0 (9) θ O C C O O C H 3 : d θ O C C O O C H 3 d t = k 4 θ C O O C H 3 θ C O − k 5 θ O C C O O C H 3 θ O C H 3 = 0 Through micro-kinetic modeling we found that COOCH3, the key intermediate, has the highest coverage on the three surfaces when the reaction reached equilibrium, as shown in Table 5 . This phenomenon has also been observed in our previous work on the Pd(111) surface [48] and the experimental study of Guo et al. [13]. It is not difficult to understand that the consumption rate of COOCH3 is much lower than that of the generation of COOCH3, which leads to the massive accumulation of COOCH3 on the three surfaces. It also reflects that the rate-determining step plays an important role in the whole catalytic reaction process, and it controls the rate of reaction to a great extent. Due to the high coverage of COOCH3 in the reaction process on these three surfaces, the effect of adsorbate-adsorbate interactions (mainly COOCH3−COOCH3) on the reaction and the coverage of COOCH3 had also been studied. For the region where DMO is synthesized on surfaces, the coverage with the co-adsorption of two COOCH3 almost reaches 1. In order to explore the effect of high coverage COOCH3 on the reaction process, we further constructed a co-adsorption model of three COOCH3 on the Pd(100) surface to reflect the influence of adsorbate-adsorbate interactions (mainly COOCH3−COOCH3) on the adsorption and reaction. We found that the average adsorption energy of COOCH3 in 3COOCH3 * is -204.8 kJ mol−1, which is only 0.4 kJ·mol−1 higher than that COOCH3 *. We also studied the effect of the third COOCH3 toward two COOCH3 coupling to DMO, the result showed that the interaction had little effect on the coupling reaction, the activation energy required for the reaction in the presence and absence of the third COOCH3 is only with a difference of 4.2 kJ·mol−1, corresponding structures and potential energy diagram are shown in Fig. 14 . So we believe that adsorbate-adsorbate interaction (mainly COOCH3−COOCH3) do not play a significant role on these surfaces and has a negligible influence on the coverage during the CO oxidative coupling to DMO reaction system. And we believe that our research results can provide some theoretical basis for experimental scientists. The rates for each product (DMO and DMC) can be obtained via the following formula [61]: (10) r D M O = k 3 θ C O O C H 3 2 + k 5 θ O C C O O C H 3 θ O C H 3 (11) r DMC = k 6 θ C O O C H 3 θ O C H 3 The formation rates of DMO at the temperature range of 375–415 K (the suitable temperature range for the reaction) [8] are shown in Table 6 . The results show that the increase of temperature is favorable for the formation of DMO. And the order for DMO formation rates on these three surfaces is Pd(100) > Pd(110) > Pd(211). Besides activity, selectivity is also an important indicator to judge the performance of catalyst. Therefore the study of selectivity to DMO on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces has also been carried out. 3.5 The selectivity of DMO on Pd(100), Pd(110) and Pd(211) surfaces The adsorption sites on the Pd(100) surface are fewer than that on Pd(111) and Pd(211) surfaces, and the stable adsorption configurations of reactants on the Pd(100) surface are the most fewest, implying the reaction activity sites of Pd(100) surface is relative unitary. However, the selectivity of DMO on these surfaces is unclear. Therefore, the generation of DMC on each surface is investigated to check the selectivity of different surfaces. The generation mechanisms of DMC on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces have been displayed in Fig. 15 . When COOCH3, CO and OCH3 are co-adsorbed on the surface, two reactions will be occurred. One is that OCH3 combining with CO leads to the formation of another intermediate COOCH3. The other is that OCH3 interacts with COOCH3, which will form DMC product. On the Pd(100) surface, DMC formation needs a very high energy barrier of 174.9 kJ·mol−1 at transition state [TS6Pd(100)]. The distance between O of OCH3 and C of COOCH3 is shorten to 1.348 Å in DMC from 2.408 Å in TS6Pd(100), which is lightly higher than that of forming DMO with an energy difference of 3.6 kJ·mol−1 comparing with the relative energy of TS3. An energy barrier of 132.6 kJ·mol−1 is needed to be overcome to generate DMC on the Pd(110) surface, implying that the formation of DMC is relative easy. The formation of DMC on the Pd(211) surface needs an activation energy of 254.3 kJ·mol−1, which is higher that of DMO with a difference of 10.3 kJ·mol−1. The formation rates of DMC at the temperature range of 375–415 K can also been in Table 6. By comparing the formation rates of DMO and DMC on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces, we can see that DMO is the favorable product on the Pd(100) surface with high reaction rate comparing to the formation of DMC. However, Pd(110) surface exhibits high selectivity to DMC, while Pd(211) surface does not take overwhelming advantage to produce DMO. 3.6 Effects of different crystal faces on the CO oxidative coupling to DMO According to the CO oxidative coupling to DMO reaction, the structural properties of different Pd crystal surfaces determines the mode of CO participating in the reaction. Single CO can adsorb at top, bridge and hollow sites on the Pd(100) surface, however, only CO at bridge and hollow sites can co-adsorb with OCH3 on this surface. CO at bridge or hollow site is consumed to the initial reaction to the formation of COOCH3 with similar energy barriers, and the bridge−CO mainly takes part in the reaction with the increase of surface reaction species. On Pd(110) surface, CO can stably exist at top, two bridge, fcc and hcp sites, and linear CO at top site is mainly consumed on the formation of DMO. The same phenomenon is investigated on the Pd(111) surface [48], CO at top site participates in the formation of COOCH3 with the lowest energy barrier. Five surface adsorption sites including top, bridge, fcc, hcp and hollow on the Pd(211) surface are considered for the adsorption of CO, and which can stably exist on these five sites. CO at bridge site on the Pd(211) surface is mainly consumed leading to the formation of intermediate COOCH3 with low energy barrier. We can see that the consumption of CO with different adsorption modes accords to the different surface characteristics, and this is why there is controversy about the site of CO participating in the reaction. Numerous theoretical calculations [47] and experiments [13] had indicated that CO mainly took part in this reaction in the form of top adsorption. However, bridge adsorption of CO is mainly consumed in the CO oxidative coupling reaction [62,50]. As the case for the dissociation of NO on Rh(100), (110) and (111) surface, NO at bridge site was dissociated on the Rh(100) surface, NO at the long bridge site was cleaved on the Rh (110) surface, while hcp is the main reaction site for the dissociation of NO [63]. The rate-limiting step for forming DMO on these three surfaces is the coupling reaction leading to the formation of new CC bond, implying the most difficult and critical step is the conversion of C1 species into C2 species. However, the favorable path and the key coupling mode on these surfaces are different. COOCH3−COOCH3 coupling path is the favorable one on the Pd(100) surface and two COOCH3 coupling is the key step, while the optimal path is CO−COOCH3 coupling and the coupling step resulting in OCCOOCH3 is the rate-determining step on Pd(110) and (211) surfaces. It is not difficult to understand that the favorable routes for CO coupling to DMO reaction are different on different surfaces. Similar phenomenon had been found in our previous study on the reaction of syngas to ethanol on Rh(211) and (111) surfaces [64]. The CC bond is mainly formed by CO insertion into CH3 leading to CH3CO on the Rh(111) surface. On the Rh(211) surface, CHO insertion into CH3 to generate CH3CHO followed by the formation of CC bond. Different CC forming ways lead to different formation paths of ethanol on Rh(211) and (111) surfaces. We also found that the rate-determining steps are different for the dehydrogenation of CH4 on Rh(111), (110) and (100) surfaces [65], therefore different main intermediates were obtained. CH is the key intermediate on the Rh(111) and (100) surfaces, while CH2 is the main one on the Rh(110) surface. The catalytic activities of different surfaces aiming at CO oxidative coupling reaction are greatly different. Pd(100) surface exhibits a good catalytic activity with an energy barrier of 129.9 kJ·mol−1, and there is lightly higher than the Pd(111) surface with a difference of 9.3 kJ·mol−1 [48], but greatly lower than Pd(110) and (211) surfaces with large difference of 47.1 and 109.7 kJ·mol−1. The outstanding catalytic activity of Pd(100) and (111) surfaces may result from the relative flat surface, which make absorbed species easily move and react on the surface [66]. However, the final elementary step for generating DMO via CO coupling COOCH3 on Pd (110) and (211) surfaces can only occur on two different edges, the large distance between the reactants shows a detrimental effect on the reaction. In addition, activity greatly relies on the electronic band structure. The farther d-band center from the Fermi energy, the higher reaction activity of catalyst for certain reactions [67]. The density of states (DOS) analysis [68,69] for these three surfaces is carried out, and the d-band centers for Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces are -2.21, -1.96 and -1.61 eV (Fig. 16 ), respectively. It can be seen that the d-band center farther to the Fermi level facilitates a lower activation barrier for CO oxidative coupling reaction. The d-band center is obtained by the following formula [70,71]: (12) ε d = ∫ − ∞ + ∞ E ρ d ( E ) d E ∫ − ∞ ∞ ρ d ( E ) d E where ρ d represents the density of states projected onto d-band of Pd(100), Pd(110) and Pd(211) surfaces and E is the energy of d-band. 4 Conclusions We compared and analyzed the reaction mechanism of CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces. Different surface structures greatly affect the adsorption of reactants and reaction mechanism. CO takes part in the oxidative coupling reaction at different surfaces with different adsorption modes, resulting in the consumption of CO at top site or bridge site depending on the surface structure. The favorable paths are various on three surfaces. COOCH3−COOCH3 coupling route is the favorable on the Pd(100) surface, while CO−COOCH3 coupling route is the optimal on Pd(110) and (211) surfaces. The catalytic activity of these three surfaces are following the order of Pd(100) > Pd(110) > Pd(211), implying surface structures affect the catalytic activity. And there is a structural sensitivity of different surfaces to product formation, and Pd(100) surface exhibits higher selectivity to DMO than that of Pd(211) and (110) surfaces. coredata.dc:description: CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate (DMO) on Pd(100), (110) and (211) surfaces have been investigated through the density functional theory (DFT) method together with periodic slab models. Effect of different surface structures on adsorption, reaction and catalytic activity has been explored. CO at different adsorption sites participated in the oxidative coupling reaction according to the surface structure. CO at bridge or hollow site was consumed for the coupling reaction on the Pd(100) surface, and the favorable route was COOCH3-COOCH3 coupling path. While CO-COOCH3 coupling route was the optimal on Pd(110) and (211) surfaces, CO at top and bridge site took part in the reaction, respectively. Pd(100) surface exhibited higher catalytic activity and selectivity to DMO than Pd(110) and (211) surfaces.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the effect of surface structure for Pd catalyst on CO oxidative coupling to dimethyl oxalate
